lat_deg = 46.779389 | lon_deg = 10.840306 }} '''Ötzi''' ({{IPA-de|ˈœtsi|-|De-Oetzi-pronunciation.ogg}}), also called '''the Iceman''', the '''Similaun Man''' ({{lang-it|Mummia del Similaun}}), the '''Man from Hauslabjoch''', the '''Tyrolean Iceman''', and the '''Hauslabjoch mummy''', is the well-preserved [[natural mummy]] of a man who lived between [[34th_century_BC|3400]] and [[31st_century_BC|3100 BCE]].{{cite journal |last=Bonani |first=Georges |last2=Ivy |first2=Susan D. |display-authors=etal |date=1994 |title=AMS {{SimpleNuclide2|Carbon|14}} Age Determination of Tissue, Bone and Grass Samples from the Ötzal Ice Man |url=http://digitalcommons.library.arizona.edu/objectviewer?o=http%3A%2F%2Fradiocarbon.library.arizona.edu%2FVolume36%2FNumber2%2Fazu_radiocarbon_v36_n2_247_250_v.pdf |journal=Radiocarbon |publisher=The Department of Geosciences, The University of Arizona |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages= 247–250 |access-date=4 February 2016 |doi=10.1017/s0033822200040534}} The mummy was found in September 1991 in the [[Ötztal Alps]], hence the nickname "Ötzi", near [[Similaun]] mountain and Hauslabjoch on the border between Austria and Italy.{{citation|author=James Neill|title=Otzi, the 5,300 Year Old Iceman from the Alps: Pictures & Information|date=27 October 2004|url=http://www.wilderdom.com/evolution/OtziIcemanAlpsPictures.htm|accessdate=8 March 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312171223/http://wilderdom.com/evolution/OtziIcemanAlpsPictures.htm|archivedate=12 March 2007|df=dmy-all}}{{better source|date=October 2017}} He is Europe's oldest known natural human mummy, and has offered an unprecedented view of [[Chalcolithic]] (Copper Age) Europeans. His body and belongings are displayed in the [[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]] in [[Bolzano]], [[South Tyrol]], Italy. ==Discovery== Ötzi was found on 19 September 1991 by two German tourists, at an elevation of {{convert|3210|m|ft}} on the east ridge of the [[Fineilspitze]] in the [[Ötztal Alps]] on the Austrian–Italian border. The tourists, Helmut and Erika Simon, were walking off the path between the mountain passes Hauslabjoch and Tisenjoch. They believed that the body was of a recently deceased mountaineer.[http://www.iceman.it/en/node/233 Description of the Discovery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111213024011/http://www.iceman.it/en/node/233 |date=13 December 2011 }} at the South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology web site The next day, a mountain [[Gendarmerie|gendarme]] and the keeper of the nearby Similaunhütte first attempted to remove the body, which was frozen in ice below the torso, using a pneumatic drill and ice-axes, but had to give up due to bad weather. The next day, eight groups visited the site, among whom happened to be the famous mountaineers [[Hans Kammerlander]] and [[Reinhold Messner]]. The body was semi-officially extracted on 22 September and officially salvaged the following day. It was transported to the office of the medical examiner in [[Innsbruck]], together with other objects found. On 24 September the find was examined there by [[archaeologist]] Konrad Spindler of the [[University of Innsbruck]]. He dated the find to be "about four thousand years old", based on the typology of an axe among the retrieved objects.{{cite book |title=Iceman: Uncovering the Life and Times of a Prehistoric Man Found in an Alpine Glacier |author=Brenda Fowler |page=37 ''ff'' |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-226-25823-2}}{{cite web |title=The Incredible Age of the Find |url=http://www.iceman.it/en/oetzi-age |publisher=[[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]] |date=2013 |accessdate=3 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150624085502/http://www.iceman.it/en/oetzi-age |archivedate=24 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} At the [[Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)|Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye of 1919]], the border between [[North Tyrol|North]] and [[South Tyrol]] was defined as the [[drainage divide|watershed]] of the rivers [[Inn (river)|Inn]] and [[Etsch]]. However, near Tisenjoch the (now withdrawn) glacier complicated establishing the watershed at the time and the border was established too far north. Therefore, although Ötzi's find site drains to the Austrian side, surveys in October 1991 showed that the body had been located {{convert|92.56|m|yd|2}} inside Italian territory as delineated in 1919{{coord|46|46|45.8|N|10|50|25.1|E|display=title}}.[http://www.iceman.it/en/node/241 The Border Question] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008075754/http://www.iceman.it/en/node/241 |date=8 October 2011 }}, at the museum site The province of South Tyrol therefore claimed property rights, but agreed to let Innsbruck University finish its scientific examinations. Since 1998, it has been on display at the [[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]] in [[Bolzano]], the capital of South Tyrol. ==Scientific analyses== The corpse has been extensively examined, measured, [[X-ray]]ed, and dated. Tissues and intestinal contents have been examined microscopically, as have the items found with the body. In August 2004, frozen bodies of three [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] soldiers killed during the [[Battle of San Matteo]] (1918) were found on the mountain [[Punta San Matteo]] in [[Trentino]]. One body was sent to a museum in the hope that research on how the environment affected its preservation would help unravel Ötzi's past.{{citation|title=WWI bodies are found on glacier|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3592268.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=23 August 2004|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630025333/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3592268.stm|archivedate=30 June 2006|df=dmy-all}} ===Body=== [[File:OetzitheIceman-glacier-199109a.jpg|thumb|250px|Ötzi the Iceman while still frozen in the glacier, photographed by Helmut Simon upon the discovery of the body in September 1991|alt=Ötzi the Iceman half uncovered, face down in a pool of water with iced banks]] By current estimates (2016), at the time of his death Ötzi was five-foot-three-inches tall, weighed about a hundred and ten pounds, and was about 45 years of age.{{citation|author=Rory Carroll|title=Iceman is defrosted for gene tests: New techniques may link Copper Age shepherd to present-day relatives|url=https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,373487,00.html|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=26 September 2000}} When his body was found, it weighed {{convert|13.750|kg|lboz}}.{{cite web |last1=transcript |title=Iceman Reborn |url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/ancient/iceman-reborn.html |website=PBS |accessdate=September 13, 2018}}{{Citation|last=Egarter-Vigl|first=Eduard|title=The Chalcolithic Mummy, Volume 3, In Search of Immortality|year=2006|publisher=Folio Verlag|chapter=The Preservation of the Iceman Mummy|editor=Marco Samadelli|page=54|isbn=978-3-85256-337-4}} Because the body was covered in ice shortly after his death, it had only partially deteriorated. Initial reports claimed that his [[Human penis|penis]] and most of his [[scrotum]] were missing, but this was later shown to be unfounded.{{cite web|url=http://factsanddetails.com/world/cat56/sub362/item1496.html|title=OTZI, THE ICEMAN - Facts and Details|first=Jeffrey|last=Hays|website=factsanddetails.com|accessdate=2 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501201515/http://factsanddetails.com/world/cat56/sub362/item1496.html|archivedate=1 May 2017|df=dmy-all}} Analysis of pollen, dust grains and the [[isotope|isotopic]] composition of his [[tooth enamel]] indicates that he spent his childhood near the present village of [[Feldthurns]], north of Bolzano, but later went to live in valleys about 50 kilometres farther north.{{citation|author=Wolfgang Müller|title=Origin and Migration of the Alpine Iceman|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/302/5646/862|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|date=31 October 2003|volume=302|issue=5646|pages=862–866|publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]]|doi=10.1126/science.1089837|accessdate=18 October 2007|laysummary=http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/identity.htm|laysource=Mummy Tombs|laydate=16 December 2007|pmid=14593178|name-list-format=vanc|display-authors=1|last2=Fricke|first2=H|last3=Halliday|first3=AN|last4=McCulloch|first4=MT|last5=Wartho|first5=JA|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020040718/http://sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/302/5646/862|archivedate=20 October 2007|df=dmy-all}} In 2009, a [[X-ray computed tomography|CAT]] scan revealed that the stomach had shifted upward to where his lower lung area would normally be. Analysis of the contents revealed the partly digested remains of [[ibex]] meat, confirmed by DNA analysis, suggesting he had a meal less than two hours before his death. Wheat grains were also found.{{cite news | first = Ker | last = Than | url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/06/110623-iceman-mummy-otzi-meal-goat-stomach-science/ | title = Iceman's Stomach Sampled—Filled With Goat Meat | date = 23 June 2011 | accessdate = 24 June 2011 | publisher = [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110626140019/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2011/06/110623-iceman-mummy-otzi-meal-goat-stomach-science | archivedate = 26 June 2011 | df = dmy-all }} It is believed that Ötzi most likely had a few slices of a dried, fatty meat, probably bacon which came from a wild goat in South Tyrol, Italy.{{cite web|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-01-iceman-oetzi-meal-stone-age.html|title=Iceman Oetzi's last meal was 'Stone Age bacon'|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107024811/https://phys.org/news/2017-01-iceman-oetzi-meal-stone-age.html|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} Analysis of Ötzi's intestinal contents showed two meals (the last one consumed about eight hours before his death), one of [[chamois]] meat, the other of [[red deer]] and herb bread; both were eaten with roots and fruits. The grain also eaten with both meals was a highly processed [[einkorn]] wheat bran,{{citation|author=T.G. Holden|chapter=The Food Remains from the Colon of the Tyrolean Ice Man|editor1=Keith Dobney|editor2=Terry O'Connor|title=Bones and the Man: Studies in Honour of Don Brothwell|location=Oxford|publisher=Oxbow Books|year=2002|pages=35–40|isbn=978-1-84217-060-1}} quite possibly eaten in the form of bread. In the proximity of the body, and thus possibly originating from the Iceman's provisions, chaff and grains of einkorn and [[barley]], and seeds of [[flax]] and [[Poppy (flower)|poppy]] were discovered, as well as kernels of [[Prunus spinosa|sloes]] (small plumlike fruits of the blackthorn tree) and various seeds of berries growing in the wild.{{citation|author=A.G. Heiss & K. Oeggl |title= The plant macro-remains from the Iceman site (Tisenjoch, Italian-Austrian border, eastern Alps): new results on the glacier mummy's environment |journal=Veget Hist Archaeobot |date= 19 February 2008 |doi=10.1007/s00334-007-0140-8|volume=18|pages=23–35}} [[Hair analysis]] was used to examine his diet from several months before. Pollen in the first meal showed that it had been consumed in a mid-altitude [[conifer]] forest, and other pollens indicated the presence of wheat and [[legume]]s, which may have been domesticated crops. Pollen grains of [[Ostrya|hop-hornbeam]] were also discovered. The pollen was very well preserved, with the cells inside remaining intact, indicating that it had been fresh (estimated about two hours old) at the time of Ötzi's death, which places the event in the spring, or early summer. Einkorn wheat is harvested in the late summer, and [[sloe]]s in the autumn; these must have been stored from the previous year. High levels of both copper particles and [[arsenic]] were found in Ötzi's hair. This, along with Ötzi's copper axe blade, which is 99.7% pure copper, has led scientists to speculate that Ötzi was involved in copper [[smelting]].{{citation|title=Iceman's final meal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2262615.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=16 September 2002|author1=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150330095330/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/2262615.stm|archivedate=30 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} By examining the proportions of Ötzi's [[tibia]], [[femur]] and [[human pelvis|pelvis]], Christopher Ruff has determined that Ötzi's lifestyle included long walks over hilly terrain. This degree of mobility is not characteristic of other [[Copper Age]] Europeans. Ruff proposes that this may indicate that Ötzi was a high-altitude shepherd.{{citation|author=Christopher Ruff|title=Body size, body proportions, and mobility in the Tyrolean "Iceman"|journal=Journal of Human Evolution|date=July 2006|volume=51|issue=1 |pages=91–101|doi=10.1016/j.jhevol.2006.02.001|pmid=16549104|last2=Holt|first2=BM|last3=Sládek|first3=V|last4=Berner|first4=M|last5=Murphy Jr|first5=WA|last6=Zur Nedden|first6=D|last7=Seidler|first7=H|last8=Recheis|first8=W}} Using modern 3-D technology, a facial reconstruction has been created for the South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology in Bolzano, Italy. It shows Ötzi looking old for his 45 years, with deep-set brown eyes, a beard, a furrowed face, and sunken cheeks. He is depicted looking tired and ungroomed.{{cite news|first=Rossella |last=Lorenzi |url=http://news.discovery.com/history/otzi-face-reconstruction-110225.html |title=The Iceman Mummy: Finally Face to Face |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=24 June 2011 |publisher=[[Discovery News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619001445/http://news.discovery.com/history/otzi-face-reconstruction-110225.html |archivedate=19 June 2011 }} ===Health=== Ötzi apparently had [[whipworm]] (''Trichuris trichiura''), an intestinal [[parasite]]. During [[computed tomography|CT]] scans, it was observed that three or four of his right ribs had been cracked when he had been lying face down after death, or where the ice had crushed his body. One of his fingernails (of the two found) shows three [[Beau's lines]] indicating he was sick three times in the six months before he died. The last incident, two months before he died, lasted about two weeks.{{citation|author=James H. Dickson|author2=Klaus Oeggl|author3=Linda L. Handly|title=The Iceman Reconsidered|url=http://students.washington.edu/mastyles/eng198spring06/iceman_reconsidered.pdf|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012023432/http://students.washington.edu/mastyles/eng198spring06/iceman_reconsidered.pdf|archivedate=12 October 2008|journal=[[Scientific American]]|date=May 2003|pages=70–79|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} Also, it was found that his [[epidermis (skin)|epidermis]], the outer skin layer, was missing, a natural process from his mummification in ice.{{citation|author=James M. Deem|title=Ötzi: Iceman of the Alps: His health|url=http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/health.htm|publisher=Mummy Tombs|date=3 January 2008|accessdate=6 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113232822/http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/health.htm|archivedate=13 November 2006|df=dmy-all}} Ötzi's teeth showed considerable internal deterioration from cavities. These oral pathologies may have been brought about by his grain-heavy, high carbohydrate diet.{{cite web |url=http://news.discovery.com/history/oetzi-iceman-bad-teeth-110615.html |title=Iceman Had Bad Teeth : Discovery News |publisher=News.discovery.com |date=15 June 2011 |accessdate=15 September 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925182225/http://news.discovery.com/history/oetzi-iceman-bad-teeth-110615.html |archivedate=25 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }} DNA analysis in February 2012 revealed that Ötzi was [[lactose intolerance|lactose intolerant]], supporting the theory that lactose intolerance was still common at that time, despite the increasing spread of agriculture and dairying.{{cite web|url=http://news.discovery.com/history/oetzi-iceman-mummy-blood-120502.html|title=Iceman Lived a While After Arrow Wound|author=|work=DNews|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819212358/http://news.discovery.com/history/oetzi-iceman-mummy-blood-120502.html|archivedate=19 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} ===Skeletal details and tattooing=== Ötzi had a total of 61 [[tattoo]]s (or [[Soot tattoo]]s), consisting of 19 groups of black lines ranging from 1 to 3 mm in thickness and 7 to 40 mm long.{{Citation|last=Samadelli |first=M |author2=M Melis |author3=M Miccoli |author4=E Egarter-Vigl |author5=AR Zink |title=Complete Mapping of the Tattoos of the 5300-year-old Tyrolean Iceman |journal=Journal of Cultural Heritage |date=2015 |volume=16 |number=5 |pages=753–758 |doi=10.1016/j.culher.2014.12.005}} These include groups of parallel lines running along the longitudinal axis of his body and to both sides of the [[Lumbar vertebrae|lumbar spine]], as well as a [[cruciform]] mark behind the right knee and on the right ankle, and parallel lines around the left wrist. The greatest concentration of markings is found on his legs, which together exhibit 12 groups of lines.{{cite web |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/1113319184/scan-finds-new-tattoos-on-5300-year-old-iceman-012215/ |title=Scan finds new tattoos on 5300-year-old Iceman |last1=Deter-Wolf |first1=Aaron |date=22 January 2015 |access-date=16 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117033016/http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/1113319184/scan-finds-new-tattoos-on-5300-year-old-iceman-012215/ |archivedate=17 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }} A microscopic examination of samples collected from these tattoos revealed that they were created from pigment manufactured out of fireplace ash or soot.{{Citation|last=Pabst |first=M.A. |author2=I Letofsky-Papst |author3=E Bock |author4=M Moser |author5=L Dorfer |author6=E Egarter-Vigl |author7=F Hoffer |title=The Tattoos of the Tyrolean Iceman: A Light Microscopical, Ultrastructural and Element Analytical Study |journal=Journal of Archaeological Science |date=2009 |volume=36 |pages=2335–2341 |doi=10.1016/j.jas.2009.06.016}} [[Radiology|Radiological]] examination of Ötzi's bones showed "age-conditioned or strain-induced degeneration" corresponding to many tattooed areas, including [[osteochondrosis]] and slight [[spondylosis]] in the lumbar spine and wear-and-tear degeneration in the knee and especially in the ankle joints.{{Citation|last=Spindler|first=Konrad|title=The man in the ice|year=1995|publisher=Phoenix|isbn=0-7538-1260-6|pages=178–184}} It has been speculated that these tattoos may have been related to pain relief treatments similar to [[acupressure]] or [[acupuncture]]. If so, this is at least 2,000 years before their previously known earliest use in China (c. 1000 BCE).{{Citation|last=Dorfer|first=L |author2=M Moser |author3=F Bahr |author4=K Spindler |author5=E Egarter-Vigl |author6=S Giullén |author7=G Dohr |author8=T Kenner |title=A medical report from the stone age? |journal=The Lancet|date=September 1999 |volume=354 |pages=1023–1025 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(98)12242-0 |pmid=10501382}} Recent research into archaeological evidence for ancient tattooing has confirmed that Ötzi is the oldest tattooed human mummy yet discovered.{{cite web |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/1113410697/its-official-otzi-the-iceman-has-the-oldest-tattoos-in-the-world-111115/ |title=It’s official: Ötzi the Iceman has the oldest tattoos in the world |last1=Deter-Wolf |first1=Aaron |date=11 November 2015 |access-date=16 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151115131532/http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/1113410697/its-official-otzi-the-iceman-has-the-oldest-tattoos-in-the-world-111115/ |archivedate=15 November 2015 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite journal|last=Deter-Wolf |first=Aaron |last2=Robitaille |first2=Benoît |last3=Krutak |first3=Lars |last4=Galliot |first4=Sébastien |title=The World's Oldest Tattoos |journal=Journal of Archaeological Science:Reports |volume=5 |pages=19–24 |date=February 2016 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352409X15301772 |doi=10.1016/j.jasrep.2015.11.007}} ===Clothes and shoes=== [[File:Archeoparc - Museum Ötzi Kleidung.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Archeoparc (''Schnals valley / South Tyrol''). Museum: Reconstruction of the neolithic clothes worn by Ötzi]] [[File:Ötzischuh 2.jpg|thumb|left|upright|An artist's impression of Ötzi's right shoe|alt=Line drawing of a right shoe]] Ötzi wore a cloak made of woven grassIn the book ''Cookwise'' by Shirley Corriher, the point is made (in relation to cooking) that plant leaves have a waterproof, waxy [[cuticle]] which makes raindrops roll off, with the comment "it was interesting that the 5,000-year-old Alpine traveler ... had a grass raincoat": {{citation|author=Shirley O. Corriher|authorlink=Shirley Corriher|title=Cookwise: The Hows and Whys of Successful Cooking|location=New York, N.Y.|publisher=[[William Morrow and Company]]|year=1997|page=312|isbn=978-0-688-10229-6}} and a coat, a belt, a pair of leggings, a loincloth and shoes, all made of leather of different skins. He also wore a bearskin cap with a leather chin strap. The shoes were waterproof and wide, seemingly designed for walking across the snow; they were constructed using bearskin for the soles, deer hide for the top panels, and a netting made of tree bark. Soft grass went around the foot and in the shoe and functioned like modern socks. The coat, belt, leggings and loincloth were constructed of vertical strips of leather sewn together with [[sinew]]. His belt had a pouch sewn to it that contained a cache of useful items: a scraper, drill, flint flake, bone awl and a dried fungus.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iceman.it/en/node/275|title=The Belt and Pouch|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology|access-date=23 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311083938/http://www.iceman.it/en/node/275|archivedate=11 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} The shoes have since been reproduced by a Czech academic, who said that "because the shoes are actually quite complex, I'm convinced that even 5,300 years ago, people had the equivalent of a [[Shoemaker|cobbler]] who made shoes for other people". The reproductions were found to constitute such excellent footwear that it was reported that a Czech company offered to purchase the rights to sell them.{{citation|author=Katka Krosnar|title=Now you can walk in footsteps of 5,000-year-old Iceman – wearing his boots|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1494238/Now-you-can-walk-in-footsteps-of-5000-year-old-Iceman-wearing-his-boots.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=17 July 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629175118/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1494238/Now-you-can-walk-in-footsteps-of-5000-year-old-Iceman-wearing-his-boots.html|archivedate=29 June 2011|df=dmy-all}} However, a more recent hypothesis by British archaeologist [[Jacqui Wood]] says that Ötzi's "shoes" were actually the upper part of [[snowshoes]]. According to this theory, the item currently interpreted as part of a "backpack" is actually the wood frame and netting of one snowshoe and animal hide to cover the face. {{cite web | url = http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/courtsocial/article1814891.ece | title = Iceman was wearing 'earliest snowshoes'| accessdate = 24 November 2013| publisher = [[The Times]]| date=21 February 2005| author = Hammond, Norman| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141129034417/http://www.stonepages.com/news/archives/001167.html| archivedate=29 November 2014}} The leather loincloth and hide coat were made from sheepskin. Genetic analysis showed that the sheep species was nearer to modern domestic European sheep than to wild sheep; the items were made from the skins of at least four animals. Part of the coat was made from domesticated goat belonging to a mitochondrial [[haplogroup]] (a common female ancestor) that inhabits central Europe today. The coat was made from several animals from two different species and was stitched together with hides available at the time. The leggings were made from domesticated goat leather. A similar set of 6,500-year-old leggings discovered in Switzerland were made from goat leather which may indicate the goat leather was specifically chosen. Shoelaces were made from the European genetic population of cattle. The quiver was made from wild [[roe deer]], the fur hat was made from a genetic lineage of [[brown bear]] which lives in the region today. Writing in the journal ''[[Scientific Reports]]'', researchers from Ireland and Italy reported their analysis of [[mitochondrial DNA]], that was extracted from nine fragments from six of his garments, including his loin cloth and fur cap.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/18/it-becometh-the-iceman-otzi-clothing-study-reveals-stylish-secrets-of-leather-loving-ancient|title=It becometh the iceman: clothing study reveals stylish secrets of leather-loving ancient|first=Nicola|last=Davis|archive-date=18 August 2016|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=30 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830164637/https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/aug/18/it-becometh-the-iceman-otzi-clothing-study-reveals-stylish-secrets-of-leather-loving-ancient|date=30 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/08/otzi-iceman-european-alps-mummy-clothing-dna-leather-fur-archaeology|title=Here's What the Iceman Was Wearing When He Died 5,300 Years Ago|first=Kristin|last=Romey|date=18 August 2016|publisher=[[National Geographic]]|access-date=18 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819105927/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/08/otzi-iceman-european-alps-mummy-clothing-dna-leather-fur-archaeology/|archivedate=19 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite journal|last=O’Sullivan|first=Niall J.|last2=Teasdale|first2=Matthew D.|last3=Mattiangeli|first3=Valeria|last4=Maixner|first4=Frank|last5=Pinhasi|first5=Ron|last6=Bradley|first6=Daniel G.|last7=Zink|first7=Albert|date=18 August 2016|title=A whole mitochondria analysis of the Tyrolean Iceman’s leather provides insights into the animal sources of Copper Age clothing|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep31279|journal=[[Scientific Reports]]|language=en|volume=6|doi=10.1038/srep31279|issn=2045-2322|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818215749/http://www.nature.com/articles/srep31279|archivedate=18 August 2016|df=dmy-all}} ===Tools and equipment=== [[File:ReconstructedOetziAxe.jpg|upright|thumb|A replica of Ötzi's copper axe]] Other items found with the Iceman were a copper axe with a [[Taxus baccata|yew]] handle, a [[chert]]-bladed [[knife]] with an [[ash tree|ash]] handle and a [[quiver]] of 14 arrows with [[viburnum]] and [[dogwood]] shafts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/21/science/otzi-iceman-tools.html?rref=collection/column/trilobites|title=The Final Hours of the Iceman’s Tools|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en}}{{cite journal|last1=Petraglia|first1=Michael D.|last2=Wierer|first2=Ursula|last3=Arrighi|first3=Simona|last4=Bertola|first4=Stefano|last5=Kaufmann|first5=Günther|last6=Baumgarten|first6=Benno|last7=Pedrotti|first7=Annaluisa|last8=Pernter|first8=Patrizia|last9=Pelegrin|first9=Jacques |url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0198292 |title=The Iceman’s lithic toolkit: Raw material, technology, typology and use|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=13|issue=6|year=2018|pages=e0198292|issn=1932-6203|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0198292}} Two of the arrows, which were broken, were tipped with flint and had [[fletching]] (stabilizing fins), while the other 12 were unfinished and untipped. The arrows were found in a [[quiver]] with what is presumed to be a [[bow string]], an unidentified tool, and an [[antler]] tool which might have been used for sharpening arrow points.{{citation|author=Brenda Fowler|title=Iceman: Uncovering the Life and Times of a Prehistoric Man found in an Alpine Glacier|location=Chicago, Ill.|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|year=2001|isbn=0-226-25823-8|pages=105–106}} There was also an unfinished yew [[longbow]] that was {{convert|1.82|m|in}} long.{{citation|author=[[Norman Davies]]|title=[[Europe: A History]]|location=Oxford|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1996|isbn=0-19-820171-0}} In addition, among Ötzi's possessions were [[berry|berries]], two [[birch bark]] baskets, and two species of [[polypore]] [[mushroom]]s with leather strings through them. One of these, the [[birch bracket|birch fungus]], is known to have [[anthelmintic]] properties, and was probably used for medicinal purposes.{{Citation |author=Capasso L |title=5300 years ago, the Ice Man used natural laxatives and antibiotics |journal=Lancet |volume=352 |issue=9143 |pages=1864 |date=December 1998 |pmid=9851424 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)79939-6 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140-6736(05)79939-6 |postscript=}} The other was a type of [[tinder fungus]], included with part of what appeared to be a complex [[firelighting]] kit. The kit featured pieces of over a dozen different plants, in addition to flint and [[pyrite]] for creating sparks. Ötzi's copper [[axe]] was of particular interest. His axe's [[Axe#Parts of the axe|haft]] is {{convert|60|cm|in}} long and made from carefully worked [[Taxus#Uses and traditions|yew]] with a right-angled crook at the shoulder, leading to the blade. The {{convert|9.5|cm|in}} long axe head is made of almost pure copper, produced by a combination of [[casting]], cold [[forging]], polishing, and sharpening. Despite the fact that copper ore sources in the Alpines are known to have been exploited at the time, a study indicated that the copper in the axe came from southern [[Tuscany]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/07/07/copper-axe-owned-neolithic-hunter-otzi-iceman-came-way-tuscany/|title=Copper axe owned by Neolithic hunter Ötzi the Iceman came all the way from Tuscany|first=Nick|last=Squires|date=7 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2017|via=www.telegraph.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107080026/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/07/07/copper-axe-owned-neolithic-hunter-otzi-iceman-came-way-tuscany/|archivedate=7 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} It was let into the forked end of the crook and fixed there using [[birch-tar]] and tight leather [[Lashing (ropework)|lashing]]. The blade part of the head extends out of the lashing and shows clear signs of having been used to chop and cut. At the time, such an axe would have been a valuable possession, important both as a tool and as a [[status symbol]] for the bearer.{{cite web|url=http://www.iceman.it/en/node/277|title=The Axe – Ötzi – South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology|author=|work=iceman.it|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116010012/http://www.iceman.it/en/node/277|archivedate=16 November 2010|df=dmy-all|access-date=12 September 2010}} ===Genetic analysis=== Ötzi's full genome has been sequenced; the report on this was published on 28 February 2012.{{cite journal |last1=Keller |first1=Andreas |last2=Graefen |first2=Angela |last3=Ball |first3=Markus |last4=Matzas |first4=Mark |last5=Boisguerin |first5=Valesca |last6=Maixner |first6=Frank |last7=Leidinger |first7=Petra |last8=Backes |first8=Christina |last9=Khairat |first9=Rabab |last10=Forster |first10=Michael |last11=Stade |first11=Björn |last12=Franke |first12=Andre |last13=Mayer |first13=Jens |last14=Spangler |first14=Jessica |last15=McLaughlin |first15=Stephen |last16=Shah |first16=Minita |last17=Lee |first17=Clarence |last18=Harkins |first18=Timothy T. |last19=Sartori |first19=Alexander |last20=Moreno-Estrada |first20=Andres |last21=Henn |first21=Brenna |last22=Sikora |first22=Martin |last23=Semino |first23=Ornella |last24=Chiaroni |first24=Jacques |last25=Rootsi |first25=Siiri |last26=Myres |first26=Natalie M. |last27=Cabrera |first27=Vicente M. |last28=Underhill |first28=Peter A. |last29=Bustamante |first29=Carlos D. |last30=Vigl |first30=Eduard Egarter |display-authors=2 |date=28 February 2012 |title=New insights into the Tyrolean Iceman's origin and phenotype as inferred by whole-genome sequencing |journal=Nature Communications |volume=3 |page=698 |doi=10.1038/ncomms1701 |pmid=22426219}} The [[Y-DNA]] of Ötzi belongs to a [[Haplogroup G (Y-DNA)|subclade of G]] defined by the SNPs M201, P287, P15, L223 and L91 (G-L91, ISOGG G2a2b, former "G2a4"). He was not typed for any of the subclades downstreaming from G-L91. G-L91 is now mostly found in South [[Corsica]]. Analysis of his [[mitochondrial DNA]] showed that Ötzi belongs to the K1 subclade, but cannot be categorized into any of the three modern branches of that subclade (K1a, K1b or K1c). The new subclade has provisionally been named ''K1ö'' for ''Ötzi''.{{cite journal |last1=Ermini |first1=Luca |last2=Olivieri |first2=Cristina |last3=Rizzi |first3=Ermanno |last4=Corti |first4=Giorgio |last5=Bonnal |first5=Raoul |last6=Soares |first6=Pedro |last7=Luciani |first7=Stefania |last8=Marota |first8=Isolina |last9=De Bellis |first9=Gianluca |last10=Richards |first10=Martin B. |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2008.09.028 |pmid=18976917}} Multiplex assay study was able to confirm that the Iceman's mtDNA belongs to a previously unknown European mtDNA clade with a very limited distribution among modern data sets.{{cite journal |last1=Endicott |first1=Phillip |last2=Sanchez |first2=Juan J |last3=Pichler |first3=Irene |last4=Brotherton |first4=Paul |last5=Brooks |first5=Jerome |last6=Egarter-Vigl |first6=Eduard |last7=Cooper |first7=Alan |last8=Pramstaller |first8=Peter |year=2009 |title=Genotyping human ancient mtDNA control and coding region polymorphisms with a multiplexed Single-Base-Extension assay: The singular maternal history of the Tyrolean Iceman |journal=BMC Genetics |volume=10 |pages=29 |doi=10.1186/1471-2156-10-29 |pmid=19545382 |pmc=2717998}} By [[autosomal DNA]], Ötzi is most closely related to southern Europeans, especially to geographically isolated populations like [[Corsicans]] and [[Sardinians]].{{cite web|url=http://hudsonalpha.org/ancient-dna-reveals-genetic-relationship-between-todays-sardinians-and-neolithic-europeans|title=Ancient DNA reveals genetic relationship between today’s Sardinians and Neolithic Europeans – HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology|date=19 November 2015|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008061113/http://hudsonalpha.org/ancient-dna-reveals-genetic-relationship-between-todays-sardinians-and-neolithic-europeans|archivedate=8 August 2016|doi=10.1038/nature.2012.10130|journal=Nature|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911110500/http://www.nature.com/news/iceman-s-dna-reveals-health-risks-and-relations-1.10130|archivedate=11 September 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=http://notizie.tiscali.it/articoli/scienza/12/02/tratti-genetici-oetzi-abitanti-sardegna-corsica.html |title=Tratti genetici comuni tra la mummia Oetzi e gli attuali abitanti di Sardegna e Corsica |date=28 February 2012 |publisher=Tiscali |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302190033/http://notizie.tiscali.it/articoli/scienza/12/02/tratti-genetici-oetzi-abitanti-sardegna-corsica.html |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} DNA analysis also showed him at high risk of [[atherosclerosis]] and [[lactose intolerance]], with the presence of the [[DNA sequencing|DNA sequence]] of ''[[Borrelia burgdorferi]]'', possibly making him the earliest known human with [[Lyme disease]].{{cite news | first = Stephen S. | last = Hall | url = http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2011/11/iceman-autopsy/hall-text | title = Iceman Autopsy | may have been a different ''[[Borrelia]]'' species.{{cite journal|last1=Ames|first1=S. K.|last2=Hysom|first2=D. A.|last3=Gardner|first3=S. N.|last4=Lloyd|first4=G. S.|last5=Gokhale|first5=M. B.|last6=Allen|first6=J. Hawks|John Hawks]] suggests that Ötzi had a [[Archaic human admixture with modern humans|higher degree of Neanderthal ancestry]] than modern Europeans.{{cite web|url=http://johnhawks.net/weblog/reviews/neandertals/neandertal_dna/neandertal-ancestry-iced-2012.html|title=Neandertal ancestry "Iced"|author=John Hawks|publisher=john hawks weblog|date=15 August 2012|accessdate=17 August 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818211427/http://johnhawks.net/weblog/reviews/neandertals/neandertal_dna/neandertal-ancestry-iced-2012.html|archivedate=18 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} In October 2013, it was reported that 19 modern [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrolean]] men were descendants of Ötzi, or of a close relative of Ötzi. Scientists from the Institute of Legal Medicine at [[Innsbruck Medical University]] had analysed the DNA of over 3,700 Tyrolean male blood donors and found 19 who shared a particular genetic mutation with the 5,300-year-old man.{{cite web|date=10 October 2013|title=Link to Oetzi the Iceman found in living Austrians|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24477038|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=12 October 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012043826/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-24477038|archivedate=12 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===Blood=== In May 2012, scientists announced the discovery that Ötzi still had intact blood cells. These are the oldest complete human blood cells ever identified. In most bodies this old, the blood cells are either shrunken or mere remnants, but Ötzi's have the same dimensions as living red blood cells and resembled a modern-day sample.{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/05/120502-oldest-blood-otzi-iceman-mummy-oetzi-zink-science/|title=World's Oldest Blood Found in Famed "Iceman" Mummy|first=James|date=2 May 2012|work=National Geographic|author=Owen|accessdate=4 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062603/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/05/120502-oldest-blood-otzi-iceman-mummy-oetzi-zink-science/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite journal|last=Janko|first=Marek|last2=Stark|first2=Robert W.|last3=Zink|first3=Albert|date=7 October 2012|title=Preservation of 5300 year old red blood cells in the Iceman|journal=Journal of the Royal Society, Interface / the Royal Society|volume=9|issue=75|pages=2581–2590|doi=10.1098/rsif.2012.0174|issn=1742-5662|pmc=3427508|pmid=22552923}} ===''H. pylori'' analysis=== In 2016, researchers reported on a study from the extraction of twelve samples from the [[gastrointestinal tract]] of Ötzi to analyze the origins of the ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' in his gut. The ''H. pylori'' strain found in his gastrointestinal tract was, surprisingly, the hpAsia2 strain, a strain today found primarily in South Asian and Central Asian populations, with extremely rare occurrences in modern European populations. The strain found in Ötzi's gut is most similar to three modern individuals from Northern India; the strain itself is, of course, older than the modern Northern Indian strain.{{cite journal|last1=Maixner|first1=Frank|last2=Krause-Kyora|first2=Ben|title=The 5300-year-old Helicobacter pylori genome of the Iceman|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|date=8 Jan 2016|volume=351|issue=6269|doi=10.1126/science.aad2545|pages=162–165|pmid=26744403|pmc=4775254}} ==Cause of death== [[File:Oetzi Memorial.jpg|thumb|upright|The Ötzi memorial near Tisenjoch. Ötzi was found ca. 70 m NE of here, a place indicated with a red mark (not in this photo). The mountain in the background is the [[Fineilspitze]].]] [[File:Oetzi the Iceman Rekonstruktion 1.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Natural history|Naturalistic]] reconstruction of Ötzi – [[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]] (2011)]] The cause of death remained uncertain until 10 years after the discovery of the body.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/26/world/europe/bolzano-italy-iceman-south-tyrol-museum-of-archaeology.html?em_pos=medium&emc=edit_sc_20170327&nl=science-times&nl_art=4&nlid=76811190&ref=headline&te=1|title=Who Killed the Iceman? Clues Emerge in a Very Cold Case|publisher=The New York Times|date=26 March 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170926041602/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/26/world/europe/bolzano-italy-iceman-south-tyrol-museum-of-archaeology.html?em_pos=medium&emc=edit_sc_20170327&nl=science-times&nl_art=4&nlid=76811190&ref=headline&te=1|archivedate=26 September 2017|df=dmy-all}} It was initially believed that Ötzi died from exposure during a winter storm. Later it was speculated that Ötzi might have been a victim of a [[ritual]] [[human sacrifice|sacrifice]], perhaps for being a [[tribal chief|chieftain]].{{citation|author=Sarah Ives|title=Was ancient alpine "Iceman" killed in battle?|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/10/1030_031030_icemandeath.html|publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic News]]|date=30 October 2003|accessdate=25 October 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015063145/http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/10/1030_031030_icemandeath.html|archivedate=15 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}{{citation|author=Franco Rollo []|title=Ötzi's last meals: DNA analysis of the intestinal content of the Neolithic glacier mummy from the Alps|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2002|volume=99|issue=20|pages=12594–12599|doi=10.1073/pnas.192184599|pmid=12244211|pmc=130505|name-list-format=vanc|display-authors=1|last2=Ubaldi|first2=M|last3=Ermini|first3=L|last4=Marota|first4=I}} This explanation was inspired by theories previously advanced for the first millennium BCE [[bog body|bodies]] recovered from [[bog|peat bogs]] such as the [[Tollund Man]] and the [[Lindow Man]]. In 2001, X-rays and a CT scan revealed that Ötzi had an arrowhead lodged in his left shoulder when he died,{{citation|author=Stephanie Pain|title=Arrow points to foul play in ancient iceman's death|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn1080|publisher=[[New Scientist|NewScientistTech]]|date=26 July 2001|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823042935/http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn1080|archivedate=23 August 2014|df=dmy-all}} and a matching small tear on his coat.{{citation|author=James M. Deem|title=Ötzi: Iceman of the Alps: Scientific studies|url=http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/studies.html|date=3 January 2008|accessdate=6 January 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150902231211/http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/studies.html|archivedate=2 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} The discovery of the arrowhead prompted researchers to theorize Ötzi died of [[bleeding|blood loss]] from the wound, which would probably have been fatal even if modern medical techniques had been available.{{citation|author=Alok Jha|title=Iceman bled to death, scientists say|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2007/jun/07/archaeology.internationalnews|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=7 June 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313233825/https://www.theguardian.com/science/2007/jun/07/archaeology.internationalnews|archivedate=13 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} Further research found that the arrow's shaft had been removed before death, and close examination of the body found [[bruise]]s and cuts to the hands, wrists and chest and [[head injury|cerebral trauma]] indicative of a blow to the head. One of the cuts was to the base of his thumb that reached down to the bone but had no time to heal before his death. Currently, it is believed that Ötzi [[Exsanguination|bled to death]] after the arrow shattered the [[scapula]] and damaged nerves and blood vessels before lodging near the lung. Recent DNA analyses claim they revealed traces of blood from at least four other people on his gear: one from his knife, two from the same arrowhead, and a fourth from his coat.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2003-08-11-iceman-murder_x.htm|title=USATODAY.com – 'Iceman' was murdered, science sleuths say|author=|work=usatoday.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627042824/http://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2003-08-11-iceman-murder_x.htm|archivedate=27 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite book|last1=Fagan|first1=Brian M.|last2=Durrani|first2=Nadia|title=In the Beginning: An Introduction to Archaeology|date=25 September 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317346432|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rNOPCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA303|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205093054/https://books.google.com/books?id=rNOPCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA303|archivedate=5 February 2017|df=dmy-all}} Interpretations of these findings were that Ötzi killed two people with the same arrow, and was able to retrieve it on both occasions, and the blood on his coat was from a wounded comrade he may have carried over his back. Ötzi's posture in death (frozen body, face down, left arm bent across the chest) could support a theory that before death occurred and [[rigor mortis]] set in, the Iceman was turned onto his stomach in the effort to remove the arrow shaft.{{citation|author=Rossella Lorenzi|title=Blow to head, not arrow, killed Otzi the iceman|url=http://abc.net.au/science/news/stories/2007/2020609.htm?health|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=31 August 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011190231/http://abc.net.au/science/news/stories/2007/2020609.htm?health|archivedate=11 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}; {{citation|author=Nicole Winfield|title=Ancient murder mystery takes new turn|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20495781/?GT1=10252|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=30 August 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901210135/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20495781/?GT1=10252|archivedate=1 September 2007|df=dmy-all}} In 2010, it was proposed that Ötzi died at a much lower altitude and was buried higher in the mountains, as posited by archaeologist Alessandro Vanzetti of the [[Sapienza University of Rome]] and his colleagues.A. Vanzetti, M. Vidale, M. Gallinaro, D.W. Frayer, and L. Bondioli. "[http://antiquity.ac.uk/ant/084/ant0840681.htm The iceman as a burial] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100906094420/http://www.antiquity.ac.uk/Ant/084/ant0840681.htm |date=6 September 2010 }}."''[Antiquity (journal)|Antiquity]''. Volume: 84 Number: 325 Page: 681–692. September 2010 According to their study of the items found near Ötzi and their locations, it is possible that the iceman may have been placed above what has been interpreted as a stone burial mound but was subsequently moved with each thaw cycle that created a flowing watery mix driven by gravity before being re-frozen."[http://sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/62670/description/Prehistoric_%E2%80%98Iceman%E2%80%99_gets_ceremonial_twist Prehistoric 'Iceman' gets ceremonial twist] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830181108/http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/62670/description/Prehistoric_%E2%80%98Iceman%E2%80%99_gets_ceremonial_twist |date=30 August 2010 }}", ''[[Science News]]'', 25 September 2010. (Retrieved 19 September 2010) While archaeobotanist [[Klaus Oeggl]] of the [[University of Innsbruck]] agrees that the natural process described probably caused the body to move from the ridge that includes the stone formation, he pointed out that the paper provided no compelling evidence to demonstrate that the scattered stones constituted a burial platform. Moreover, biological anthropologist Albert Zink argues that the iceman's bones display no dislocations that would have resulted from a downhill slide and that the intact blood clots in his arrow wound would show damage if the body had been moved up the mountain. In either case, the burial theory does not contradict the possibility of a violent cause of death. ==Legal dispute== Italian law entitled the Simons to a finders' fee from the South Tyrolean provincial government of 25% of the value of Ötzi. In 1994 the authorities offered a "symbolic" reward of 10 million [[Italian lira|lire]] (€5,200), which the Simons turned down.{{citation|title='Iceman' row ends after 17 years|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7643286.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=29 September 2008|author1=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930070344/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7643286.stm|archivedate=30 September 2008|df=dmy-all}} In 2003, the Simons filed a [[lawsuit]] which asked a court in [[Bolzano]] to recognize their role in Ötzi's discovery and declare them his "official discoverers". The court decided in the Simons' favor in November 2003, and at the end of December that year the Simons announced that they were seeking US$300,000 as their fee. The provincial government decided to appeal.{{citation|author=James M. Deem|title=Ötzi: Iceman of the Alps: Finder's fee lawsuits|url=http://mummytombs.com/otzi/lawsuit.htm|publisher=Mummy Tombs|date=September 2008|accessdate=1 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081102055614/http://www.mummytombs.com/otzi/lawsuit.htm|archivedate=2 November 2008|df=dmy-all}} In addition, two people came forward to claim that they were part of the same mountaineering party that came across Ötzi and discovered the body first: *Magdalena Mohar Jarc, a retired [[Slovenia]]n climber, who alleged that she discovered the corpse first after falling into a crevice, and shortly after returning to a mountain hut, asked Helmut Simon to take photographs of Ötzi. She cited Reinhold Messner, who was also present in the mountain hut, as the witness to this.{{cite web |url=http://www.gore-ljudje.net/novosti/39391/ |title=Magdaleni ne bodo plačali za Ötzija |trans-title=Magdalena Won't Get Paid for Ötzi |newspaper=Slovenske novice |date=9 October 2008 |language=Slovenian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518064420/http://www.gore-ljudje.net/novosti/39391/ |archivedate=18 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }} *Sandra Nemeth, from Switzerland, who contended that she found the corpse before Helmut and Erika Simon, and that she spat on Ötzi to make sure that her [[DNA]] would be found on the body later. She asked for a DNA test on the remains, but experts believed that there was little chance of finding any trace.{{citation|author=Nick Pisa|title=Cold case comes to court – After 5,300 years|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1501326/Cold-case-comes-to-court---after-5300-years.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=22 October 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206113514/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1501326/Cold-case-comes-to-court---after-5300-years.html|archivedate=6 December 2008|df=dmy-all}} In 2005 the rival claims were heard by a Bolzano court. The legal case angered Mrs. Simon, who alleged that neither woman was present on the mountain that day. In 2005, Mrs. Simon's lawyer said: "Mrs. Simon is very upset by all this and by the fact that these two new claimants have decided to appear 14 years after Ötzi was found." In 2008, however, Jarc stated for a Slovene newspaper that she wrote twice to the Bolzano court in regard to her claim but received no reply whatsoever. In 2004, Helmut Simon died. Two years later, in June 2006, an appeals court affirmed that the Simons had indeed discovered the Iceman and were therefore entitled to a finder's fee. It also ruled that the provincial government had to pay the Simons' legal costs. After this ruling, Mrs. Erika Simon reduced her claim to €150,000. The provincial government's response was that the expenses it had incurred to establish a museum and the costs of preserving the Iceman should be considered in determining the finder's fee. It insisted it would pay no more than €50,000. In September 2006, the authorities appealed the case to Italy's highest court, the [[Court of Cassation (Italy)|Court of Cassation]]. On 29 September 2008 it was announced that the provincial government and Mrs. Simon had reached a settlement of the dispute, under which she would receive €150,000 in recognition of Ötzi's discovery by her and her late husband and the tourist income that it attracts.{{citation|author=Nick Squires|title=Oetzi The Iceman's discoverers finally compensated: A bitter dispute over the payment of a finder's fee for two hikers who discovered the world famous Oetzi The Iceman mummy has finally been settled|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/austria/3105153/Oetzi-the-icemans-discoverers-finally-compensated.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=29 September 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002035714/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/austria/3105153/Oetzi-the-icemans-discoverers-finally-compensated.html|archivedate=2 October 2008|df=dmy-all}} =="Ötzi's curse"== Influenced by the "[[Curse of the pharaohs]]" and the media theme of cursed mummies, claims have been made that Ötzi is [[curse]]d. The allegation revolves around the deaths of several people connected to the discovery, recovery and subsequent examination of Ötzi. It is alleged that they have died under mysterious circumstances. These persons include co-discoverer Helmut Simon{{citation|title=Iceman's finder missing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/austria/article/0,,1330689,00.html|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=19 October 2004|author1=Reuters in Vienna}}; {{citation|author=Stephen Goodwin|title=Helmut Simon: Finder of a Bronze Age man in the alpine snow [obituary]|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article30165.ece|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=25 October 2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001130155/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article30165.ece|archivedate=1 October 2007|df=dmy-all|access-date=18 March 2007}} and Konrad Spindler, the first examiner of the mummy in Austria in 1991.{{citation|author=Barbara McMahon|title=Scientist seen as latest 'victim' of Iceman|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/sciences/story/0,,1463998,00.html|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=20 April 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209193306/http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/sciences/story/0,,1463998,00.html|archivedate=9 December 2007|df=dmy-all}} To date, the deaths of seven people, of which four were accidental, have been attributed to the alleged curse. In reality hundreds of people were involved in the recovery of Ötzi and are still involved in studying the body and the artifacts found with it. The fact that a small percentage of them have died over the years has not been shown to be statistically significant.{{Citation | url = http://www.iceman.it/en/oetzi-curse | title = Is there an Ötzi curse? | work = Ötsi – the Iceman | publisher = [[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]] | accessdate = 15 August 2012 | quote = hundreds of people have worked on the Iceman project, and many years have passed since the corpse was first discovered. It is therefore not remarkable that some of those people have since died. | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120821140353/http://www.iceman.it/en/oetzi-curse | archivedate = 21 August 2012 | df = dmy-all }}''The Curse of the Ice Mummy'', a television documentary screened on UK [[Channel 4]] on 8 March 2007.
